column2: CHAPTER XXIII.
column3: CHAPTER twenty three.

column2: How Sir Pelleas loved no more Ettard by means of the Damosel of the Lake, whom he loved ever after.
column3: How Sir Pelleas loved no more Ettard by means of the Damosel of the Lake, whom he loved ever after.

column2: SIR KNIGHT PELLEAS, said the Damosel of the Lake, take your horse and come forth with me out of this country, and ye shall love a lady that shall love you.
column3: SIR KNIGHT PELLEAS, said the Damosel of the Lake, take your horse and come forth with me out of this country, and ye shall love a lady that shall love you.

column2: I will well, said Sir Pelleas, for this Lady Ettard hath done me great despite and shame, and there he told her the beginning and ending, and how he had purposed never to have arisen till that he had been dead.
column3: I will well, said Sir Pelleas, for this Lady Ettard hath done me great despite and shame, and there he told her the beginning and ending, and how he had purposed never to have arisen till that he had been dead.

column2: And now such grace God hath sent me, that I hate her as much as ever I loved her, thanked be our Lord Jesus!
column3: And now such grace God hath sent me, that I hate her as much as ever I loved her, thanked be our Lord Jesus!

column2: Thank me, said the Damosel of the Lake.
column3: Thank me, said the Damosel of the Lake.

column2: Anon Sir Pelleas armed him, and took his horse, and commanded his men to bring after his pavilions and his stuff where the Damosel of the Lake would assign.
column3: Anon Sir Pelleas armed him, and took his horse, and commanded his men to bring after his pavilions and his stuff where the Damosel of the Lake would assign.

column2: So the Lady Ettard died for sorrow, and the Damosel of the Lake rejoiced Sir Pelleas, and loved together during their life days.
column3: So the Lady Ettard died for sorrow, and the Damosel of the Lake rejoiced Sir Pelleas, and loved together during their life days.

column2: CHAPTER XXIV.
column3: CHAPTER twenty four.

column2: How Sir Marhaus rode with the damosel, and how he came to the Duke of the South Marches.
column3: How Sir Marhaus rode with the damosel, and how he came to the Duke of the South Marches.

column2: NOW turn we unto Sir Marhaus, that rode with the damosel of thirty winter of age, southward.
column3: NOW turn we unto Sir Marhaus, that rode with the damosel of thirty winter of age, southward.

column2: And so they came into a deep forest, and by fortune they were nighted, and rode long in a deep way, and at the last they came unto a courtelage, and there they asked harbour.
column3: And so they came into a deep forest, and by fortune they were nighted, and rode long in a deep way, and at the last they came unto a courtelage, and there they asked harbour.

column2: But the man of the courtelage would not lodge them for no treatise that they could treat, but thus much the good man said, An ye will take the adventure of your lodging, I shall bring you where ye shall be lodged.
column3: But the man of the courtelage would not lodge them for no treatise that they could treat, but thus much the good man said, An ye will take the adventure of your lodging, I shall bring you where ye shall be lodged.

column2: What adventure is that that I shall have for my lodging? said Sir Marhaus.
column3: What adventure is that that I shall have for my lodging? said Sir Marhaus.

column2: Ye shall wit when ye come there, said the good man.
column3: Ye shall wit when ye come there, said the good man.

column2: Sir, what adventure so it be, bring me thither I pray thee, said Sir Marhaus; for I am weary, my damosel, and my horse.
column3: Sir, what adventure so it be, bring me thither I pray thee, said Sir Marhaus; for I am weary, my damosel, and my horse.

column2: So the good man went and opened the gate, and within an hour he brought him unto a fair castle, and then the poor man called the porter, and anon he was let into the castle, and so he told the lord how he brought him a knight errant and a damosel that would be lodged with him.
column3: So the good man went and opened the gate, and within an hour he brought him unto a fair castle, and then the poor man called the porter, and anon he was let into the castle, and so he told the lord how he brought him a knight errant and a damosel that would be lodged with him.

column2: Let him in, said the lord, it may happen he shall repent that they took their lodging here.
column3: Let him in, said the lord, it may happen he shall repent that they took their lodging here.

column2: So Sir Marhaus was let in with torchlight, and there was a goodly sight of young men that welcomed him.
column3: So Sir Marhaus was let in with torchlight, and there was a goodly sight of young men that welcomed him.

column2: And then his horse was led into the stable, and he and the damosel were brought into the hall, and there stood a mighty duke and many goodly men about him.
column3: And then his horse was led into the stable, and he and the damosel were brought into the hall, and there stood a mighty duke and many goodly men about him.

column2: Then this lord asked him what he hight, and from whence he came, and with whom he dwelt.
column3: Then this lord asked him what he hight, and from whence he came, and with whom he dwelt.

column2: Sir, he said, I am a knight of King Arthur's and knight of the Table Round, and my name is Sir Marhaus, and born I am in Ireland.
column3: Sir, he said, I am a knight of King Arthur's and knight of the Table Round, and my name is Sir Marhaus, and born I am in Ireland.

column2: And then said the duke to him, That me sore repenteth: the cause is this, for I love not thy lord nor none of thy fellows of the Table Round; and therefore ease thyself this night as well as thou mayest, for as to-morn I and my six sons shall match with you.
column3: And then said the duke to him, That me sore repenteth: the cause is this, for I love not thy lord nor none of thy fellows of the Table Round; and therefore ease thyself this night as well as thou mayest, for as to morn I and my six sons shall match with you.

column2: Is there no remedy but that I must have ado with you and your six sons at once? said Sir Marhaus.
column3: Is there no remedy but that I must have ado with you and your six sons at once? said Sir Marhaus.

column2: No, said the duke, for this cause I made mine avow, for Sir Gawaine slew my seven sons in a recounter, therefore I made mine avow, there should never knight of King Arthur's court lodge with me, or come thereas I might have ado with him, but that I would have a revenging of my sons' death.
column3: No, said the duke, for this cause I made mine avow, for Sir Gawaine slew my seven sons in a recounter, therefore I made mine avow, there should never knight of King Arthur's court lodge with me, or come thereas I might have ado with him, but that I would have a revenging of my sons' death.

column2: What is your name? said Sir Marhaus; I require you tell me, an it please you.
column3: What is your name? said Sir Marhaus; I require you tell me, an it please you.

column2: Wit thou well I am the Duke of South Marches.
column3: Wit thou well I am the Duke of South Marches.

column2: Ah, said Sir Marhaus, I have heard say that ye have been long time a great foe unto my lord Arthur and to his knights.
column3: Ah, said Sir Marhaus, I have heard say that ye have been long time a great foe unto my lord Arthur and to his knights.

column2: That shall ye feel to-morn, said the duke.
column3: That shall ye feel to morn, said the duke.

column2: Shall I have ado with you? said Sir Marhaus.
column3: Shall I have ado with you? said Sir Marhaus.

column2: Yea, said the duke, thereof shalt thou not choose, and therefore take you to your chamber, and ye shall have all that to you longeth.
column3: Yea, said the duke, thereof shalt thou not choose, and therefore take you to your chamber, and ye shall have all that to you longeth.

column2: So Sir Marhaus departed and was led to a chamber, and his damosel was led unto her chamber.
column3: So Sir Marhaus departed and was led to a chamber, and his damosel was led unto her chamber.

column2: And on the morn the duke sent unto Sir Marhaus and bade make him ready.
column3: And on the morn the duke sent unto Sir Marhaus and bade make him ready.

column2: And so Sir Marhaus arose and armed him, and then there was a mass sung afore him, and brake his fast, and so mounted on horseback in the court of the castle where they should do the battle.
column3: And so Sir Marhaus arose and armed him, and then there was a mass sung afore him, and brake his fast, and so mounted on horseback in the court of the castle where they should do the battle.

column2: So there was the duke all ready on horseback, clean armed, and his six sons by him, and everych had a spear in his hand, and so they encountered, whereas the duke and his two sons brake their spears upon him, but Sir Marhaus held up his spear and touched none of them.
column3: So there was the duke all ready on horseback, clean armed, and his six sons by him, and everych had a spear in his hand, and so they encountered, whereas the duke and his two sons brake their spears upon him, but Sir Marhaus held up his spear and touched none of them.

column2: CHAPTER XXV.
column3: CHAPTER twenty five.

column2: How Sir Marhaus fought with the duke and his four sons and made them to yield them.
column3: How Sir Marhaus fought with the duke and his four sons and made them to yield them.

column2: THEN came the four sons by couple, and two of them brake their spears, and so did the other two.
column3: THEN came the four sons by couple, and two of them brake their spears, and so did the other two.

column2: And all this while Sir Marhaus touched them not.
column3: And all this while Sir Marhaus touched them not.

column2: Then Sir Marhaus ran to the duke, and smote him with his spear that horse and man fell to the earth, and so he served his sons; and then Sir Marhaus alighted down and bade the duke yield him or else he would slay him.
column3: Then Sir Marhaus ran to the duke, and smote him with his spear that horse and man fell to the earth, and so he served his sons; and then Sir Marhaus alighted down and bade the duke yield him or else he would slay him.

column2: And then some of his sons recovered, and would have set upon Sir Marhaus; then Sir Marhaus said to the duke, Cease thy sons, or else I will do the uttermost to you all.
column3: And then some of his sons recovered, and would have set upon Sir Marhaus; then Sir Marhaus said to the duke, Cease thy sons, or else I will do the uttermost to you all.

column2: Then the duke saw he might not escape the death, he cried to his sons, and charged them to yield them to Sir Marhaus; and they kneeled all down and put the pommels of their swords to the knight, and so he received them.
column3: Then the duke saw he might not escape the death, he cried to his sons, and charged them to yield them to Sir Marhaus; and they kneeled all down and put the pommels of their swords to the knight, and so he received them.

column2: And then they helped up their father, and so by their cominal assent promised to Sir Marhaus never to be foes unto King Arthur, and thereupon at Whitsuntide after to come, he and his sons, and put them in the king's grace.
column3: And then they helped up their father, and so by their cominal assent promised to Sir Marhaus never to be foes unto King Arthur, and thereupon at Whitsuntide after to come, he and his sons, and put them in the king's grace.

column2: Then Sir Marhaus departed, and within two days his damosel brought him whereas was a great tournament that the Lady de Vawse had cried.
column3: Then Sir Marhaus departed, and within two days his damosel brought him whereas was a great tournament that the Lady de Vawse had cried.

column2: And who that did best should have a rich circlet of gold worth a thousand besants.
column3: And who that did best should have a rich circlet of gold worth a thousand besants.

column2: And there Sir Marhaus did so nobly that he was renowned, and had sometime down forty knights, and so the circlet of gold was rewarded him.
column3: And there Sir Marhaus did so nobly that he was renowned, and had sometime down forty knights, and so the circlet of gold was rewarded him.

column2: Then he departed from them with great worship; and so within seven nights his damosel brought him to an earl's place, his name was the Earl Fergus, that after was Sir Tristram's knight; and this earl was but a young man, and late come into his lands, and there was a giant fast by him that hight Taulurd, and he had another brother in Cornwall that hight Taulas, that Sir Tristram slew when he was out of his mind.
column3: Then he departed from them with great worship; and so within seven nights his damosel brought him to an earl's place, his name was the Earl Fergus, that after was Sir Tristram's knight; and this earl was but a young man, and late come into his lands, and there was a giant fast by him that hight Taulurd, and he had another brother in Cornwall that hight Taulas, that Sir Tristram slew when he was out of his mind.

column2: So this earl made his complaint unto Sir Marhaus, that there was a giant by him that destroyed all his lands, and how he durst nowhere ride nor go for him.
column3: So this earl made his complaint unto Sir Marhaus, that there was a giant by him that destroyed all his lands, and how he durst nowhere ride nor go for him.

column2: Sir, said the knight, whether useth he to fight on horseback or on foot?
column3: Sir, said the knight, whether useth he to fight on horseback or on foot?

column2: Nay, said the earl, there may no horse bear him.
column3: Nay, said the earl, there may no horse bear him.

column2: Well, said Sir Marhaus, then will I fight with him on foot; so on the morn Sir Marhaus prayed the earl that one of his men might bring him whereas the giant was; and so he was, for he saw him sit under a tree of holly, and many clubs of iron and gisarms about him.
column3: Well, said Sir Marhaus, then will I fight with him on foot; so on the morn Sir Marhaus prayed the earl that one of his men might bring him whereas the giant was; and so he was, for he saw him sit under a tree of holly, and many clubs of iron and gisarms about him.

column2: So this knight dressed him to the giant, putting his shield afore him, and the giant took an iron club in his hand, and at the first stroke he clave Sir Marhaus' shield in two pieces.
column3: So this knight dressed him to the giant, putting his shield afore him, and the giant took an iron club in his hand, and at the first stroke he clave Sir Marhaus' shield in two pieces.

column2: And there he was in great peril, for the giant was a wily fighter, but at last Sir Marhaus smote off his right arm above the elbow.
column3: And there he was in great peril, for the giant was a wily fighter, but at last Sir Marhaus smote off his right arm above the elbow.

column2: Then the giant fled and the knight after him, and so he drove him into a water, but the giant was so high that he might not wade after him.
column3: Then the giant fled and the knight after him, and so he drove him into a water, but the giant was so high that he might not wade after him.

column2: And then Sir Marhaus made the Earl Fergus' man to fetch him stones, and with those stones the knight gave the giant many sore knocks, till at the last he made him fall down into the water, and so was he there dead. Then Sir Marhaus went unto the giant's castle, and there he delivered twenty-four ladies and twelve knights out of the giant's prison, and there he had great riches without number, so that the days of his life he was never poor man.
column3: And then Sir Marhaus made the Earl Fergus' man to fetch him stones, and with those stones the knight gave the giant many sore knocks, till at the last he made him fall down into the water, and so was he there dead. Then Sir Marhaus went unto the giant's castle, and there he delivered twenty four ladies and twelve knights out of the giant's prison, and there he had great riches without number, so that the days of his life he was never poor man.

column2: Then he returned to the Earl Fergus, the which thanked him greatly, and would have given him half his lands, but he would none take.
column3: Then he returned to the Earl Fergus, the which thanked him greatly, and would have given him half his lands, but he would none take.

column2: So Sir Marhaus dwelled with the earl nigh half a year, for he was sore bruised with the giant, and at the last he took his leave.
column3: So Sir Marhaus dwelled with the earl nigh half a year, for he was sore bruised with the giant, and at the last he took his leave.

column2: And as he rode by the way, he met with Sir Gawaine and Sir Uwaine, and so by adventure he met with four knights of Arthur's court, the first was Sir Sagramore le Desirous, Sir Osanna, Sir Dodinas le Savage, and Sir Felot of Listinoise; and there Sir Marhaus with one spear smote down these four knights, and hurt them sore.
column3: And as he rode by the way, he met with Sir Gawaine and Sir Uwaine, and so by adventure he met with four knights of Arthur's court, the first was Sir Sagramore le Desirous, Sir Osanna, Sir Dodinas le Savage, and Sir Felot of Listinoise; and there Sir Marhaus with one spear smote down these four knights, and hurt them sore.

column2: So he departed to meet at his day aforeset.
column3: So he departed to meet at his day aforeset.

column2: CHAPTER XXVI.
column3: CHAPTER twenty six.

column2: How Sir Uwaine rode with the damosel of sixty year of age, and how he gat the prize at tourneying.
column3: How Sir Uwaine rode with the damosel of sixty year of age, and how he gat the prize at tourneying.

column2: NOW turn we unto Sir Uwaine, that rode westward with his damosel of three score winter of age, and she brought him thereas was a tournament nigh the march of Wales.
column3: NOW turn we unto Sir Uwaine, that rode westward with his damosel of three score winter of age, and she brought him thereas was a tournament nigh the march of Wales.

column2: And at that tournament Sir Uwaine smote down thirty knights, therefore was given him the prize, and that was a gerfalcon, and a white steed trapped with cloth of gold.
column3: And at that tournament Sir Uwaine smote down thirty knights, therefore was given him the prize, and that was a gerfalcon, and a white steed trapped with cloth of gold.

column2: So then Sir Uwaine did many strange adventures by the means of the old damosel, and so she brought him to a lady that was called the Lady of the Rock, the which was much courteous.
column3: So then Sir Uwaine did many strange adventures by the means of the old damosel, and so she brought him to a lady that was called the Lady of the Rock, the which was much courteous.

column2: So there were in the country two knights that were brethren, and they were called two perilous knights, the one knight hight Sir Edward of the Red Castle, and the other Sir Hue of the Red Castle; and these two brethren had disherited the Lady of the Rock of a barony of lands by their extortion.
column3: So there were in the country two knights that were brethren, and they were called two perilous knights, the one knight hight Sir Edward of the Red Castle, and the other Sir Hue of the Red Castle; and these two brethren had disherited the Lady of the Rock of a barony of lands by their extortion.

column2: And as this knight was lodged with this lady she made her complaint to him of these two knights.
column3: And as this knight was lodged with this lady she made her complaint to him of these two knights.

column2: Madam, said Sir Uwaine, they are to blame, for they do against the high order of knighthood, and the oath that they made; and if it like you I will speak with them, because I am a knight of King Arthur's, and I will entreat them with fairness; and if they will not, I shall do battle with them, and in the defence of your right.
column3: Madam, said Sir Uwaine, they are to blame, for they do against the high order of knighthood, and the oath that they made; and if it like you I will speak with them, because I am a knight of King Arthur's, and I will entreat them with fairness; and if they will not, I shall do battle with them, and in the defence of your right.

column2: Gramercy said the lady, and thereas I may not acquit you, God shall.
column3: Gramercy said the lady, and thereas I may not acquit you, God shall.

column2: So on the morn the two knights were sent for, that they should come thither to speak with the Lady of the Rock, and wit ye well they failed not, for they came with an hundred horse.
column3: So on the morn the two knights were sent for, that they should come thither to speak with the Lady of the Rock, and wit ye well they failed not, for they came with an hundred horse.

column2: But when this lady saw them in this manner so big, she would not suffer Sir Uwaine to go out to them upon no surety nor for no fair language, but she made him speak with them over a tower, but finally these two brethren would not be entreated, and answered that they would keep that they had.
column3: But when this lady saw them in this manner so big, she would not suffer Sir Uwaine to go out to them upon no surety nor for no fair language, but she made him speak with them over a tower, but finally these two brethren would not be entreated, and answered that they would keep that they had.

column2: Well, said Sir Uwaine, then will I fight with one of you, and prove that ye do this lady wrong.
column3: Well, said Sir Uwaine, then will I fight with one of you, and prove that ye do this lady wrong.

column2: That will we not, said they, for an we do battle, we two will fight with one knight at once, and therefore if ye will fight so, we will be ready at what hour ye will assign.
column3: That will we not, said they, for an we do battle, we two will fight with one knight at once, and therefore if ye will fight so, we will be ready at what hour ye will assign.

column2: And if ye win us in battle the lady shall have her lands again. Ye say well, said Sir Uwaine, therefore make you ready so that ye be here to-morn in the defence of the lady's right.
column3: And if ye win us in battle the lady shall have her lands again. Ye say well, said Sir Uwaine, therefore make you ready so that ye be here to morn in the defence of the lady's right.

column2: CHAPTER XXVII.
column3: CHAPTER twenty seven.

column2: How Sir Uwaine fought with two knights and overcame them.
column3: How Sir Uwaine fought with two knights and overcame them.

column2: SO was there sikerness made on both parties that no treason should be wrought on neither party; so then the knights departed and made them ready, and that night Sir Uwaine had great cheer.
column3: SO was there sikerness made on both parties that no treason should be wrought on neither party; so then the knights departed and made them ready, and that night Sir Uwaine had great cheer.

column2: And on the morn he arose early and heard mass, and brake his fast, and so he rode unto the plain without the gates, where hoved the two brethren abiding him.
column3: And on the morn he arose early and heard mass, and brake his fast, and so he rode unto the plain without the gates, where hoved the two brethren abiding him.

column2: So they rode together passing sore, that Sir Edward and Sir Hue brake their spears upon Sir Uwaine.
column3: So they rode together passing sore, that Sir Edward and Sir Hue brake their spears upon Sir Uwaine.

column2: And Sir Uwaine smote Sir Edward that he fell over his horse and yet his spear brast not.
column3: And Sir Uwaine smote Sir Edward that he fell over his horse and yet his spear brast not.

column2: And then he spurred his horse and came upon Sir Hue and overthrew him, but they soon recovered and dressed their shields and drew their swords and bade Sir Uwaine alight and do his battle to the uttermost.
column3: And then he spurred his horse and came upon Sir Hue and overthrew him, but they soon recovered and dressed their shields and drew their swords and bade Sir Uwaine alight and do his battle to the uttermost.

column2: Then Sir Uwaine devoided his horse suddenly, and put his shield afore him and drew his sword, and so they dressed together, and either gave other such strokes, and there these two brethren wounded Sir Uwaine passing grievously that the Lady of the Rock weened he should have died.
column3: Then Sir Uwaine devoided his horse suddenly, and put his shield afore him and drew his sword, and so they dressed together, and either gave other such strokes, and there these two brethren wounded Sir Uwaine passing grievously that the Lady of the Rock weened he should have died.

column2: And thus they fought together five hours as men raged out of reason.
column3: And thus they fought together five hours as men raged out of reason.

column2: And at the last Sir Uwaine smote Sir Edward upon the helm such a stroke that his sword carved unto his canel bone, and then Sir Hue abated his courage, but Sir Uwaine pressed fast to have slain him.
column3: And at the last Sir Uwaine smote Sir Edward upon the helm such a stroke that his sword carved unto his canel bone, and then Sir Hue abated his courage, but Sir Uwaine pressed fast to have slain him.

column2: That saw Sir Hue: he kneeled down and yielded him to Sir Uwaine.
column3: That saw Sir Hue: he kneeled down and yielded him to Sir Uwaine.

column2: And he of his gentleness received his sword, and took him by the hand, and went into the castle together.
column3: And he of his gentleness received his sword, and took him by the hand, and went into the castle together.

column2: Then the Lady of the Rock was passing glad, and the other brother made great sorrow for his brother's death.
column3: Then the Lady of the Rock was passing glad, and the other brother made great sorrow for his brother's death.

column2: Then the lady was restored of all her lands, and Sir Hue was commanded to be at the court of King Arthur at the next feast of Pentecost.
column3: Then the lady was restored of all her lands, and Sir Hue was commanded to be at the court of King Arthur at the next feast of Pentecost.

column2: So Sir Uwaine dwelt with the lady nigh half a year, for it was long or he might be whole of his great hurts.
column3: So Sir Uwaine dwelt with the lady nigh half a year, for it was long or he might be whole of his great hurts.

column2: And so when it drew nigh the term-day that Sir Gawaine, Sir Marhaus, and Sir Uwaine should meet at the cross-way, then every knight drew him thither to hold his promise that they had made; and Sir Marhaus and Sir Uwaine brought their damosels with them, but Sir Gawaine had lost his damosel, as it is afore rehearsed.
column3: And so when it drew nigh the term day that Sir Gawaine, Sir Marhaus, and Sir Uwaine should meet at the cross way, then every knight drew him thither to hold his promise that they had made; and Sir Marhaus and Sir Uwaine brought their damosels with them, but Sir Gawaine had lost his damosel, as it is afore rehearsed.

column2: CHAPTER XXVIII.
column3: CHAPTER twenty eight.

column2: How at the year's end all three knights with their three damosels met at the fountain.
column3: How at the year's end all three knights with their three damosels met at the fountain.

column2: RIGHT so at the twelvemonths' end they met all three knights at the fountain and their damosels, but the damosel that Sir Gawaine had could say but little worship of him so they departed from the damosels and rode through a great forest, and there they met with a messenger that came from King Arthur, that had sought them well-nigh a twelvemonth throughout all England, Wales, and Scotland, and charged if ever he might find Sir Gawaine and Sir Uwaine to bring them to the court again. And then were they all glad, and so prayed they Sir Marhaus to ride with them to the king's court.
column3: RIGHT so at the twelvemonths' end they met all three knights at the fountain and their damosels, but the damosel that Sir Gawaine had could say but little worship of him so they departed from the damosels and rode through a great forest, and there they met with a messenger that came from King Arthur, that had sought them well nigh a twelvemonth throughout all England, Wales, and Scotland, and charged if ever he might find Sir Gawaine and Sir Uwaine to bring them to the court again. And then were they all glad, and so prayed they Sir Marhaus to ride with them to the king's court.

column2: And so within twelve days they came to Camelot, and the king was passing glad of their coming, and so was all the court.
column3: And so within twelve days they came to Camelot, and the king was passing glad of their coming, and so was all the court.

column2: Then the king made them to swear upon a book to tell him all their adventures that had befallen them that twelvemonth, and so they did.
column3: Then the king made them to swear upon a book to tell him all their adventures that had befallen them that twelvemonth, and so they did.

column2: And there was Sir Marhaus well known, for there were knights that he had matched aforetime, and he was named one of the best knights living.
column3: And there was Sir Marhaus well known, for there were knights that he had matched aforetime, and he was named one of the best knights living.

column2: Against the feast of Pentecost came the Damosel of the Lake and brought with her Sir Pelleas; and at that high feast there was great jousting of knights, and of all knights that were at that jousts, Sir Pelleas had the prize, and Sir Marhaus was named the next; but Sir Pelleas was so strong there might but few knights sit him a buffet with a spear.
column3: Against the feast of Pentecost came the Damosel of the Lake and brought with her Sir Pelleas; and at that high feast there was great jousting of knights, and of all knights that were at that jousts, Sir Pelleas had the prize, and Sir Marhaus was named the next; but Sir Pelleas was so strong there might but few knights sit him a buffet with a spear.

column2: And at that next feast Sir Pelleas and Sir Marhaus were made knights of the Table Round, for there were two sieges void, for two knights were slain that twelvemonth, and great joy had King Arthur of Sir Pelleas and of Sir Marhaus.
column3: And at that next feast Sir Pelleas and Sir Marhaus were made knights of the Table Round, for there were two sieges void, for two knights were slain that twelvemonth, and great joy had King Arthur of Sir Pelleas and of Sir Marhaus.

column2: But Pelleas loved never after Sir Gawaine, but as he spared him for the love of King Arthur; but ofttimes at jousts and tournaments Sir Pelleas quit Sir Gawaine, for so it rehearseth in the book of French.
column3: But Pelleas loved never after Sir Gawaine, but as he spared him for the love of King Arthur; but ofttimes at jousts and tournaments Sir Pelleas quit Sir Gawaine, for so it rehearseth in the book of French.

column2: So Sir Tristram many days after fought with Sir Marhaus in an island, and there they did a great battle, but at the last Sir Tristram slew him, so Sir Tristram was wounded that unnethe he might recover, and lay at a nunnery half a year.
column3: So Sir Tristram many days after fought with Sir Marhaus in an island, and there they did a great battle, but at the last Sir Tristram slew him, so Sir Tristram was wounded that unnethe he might recover, and lay at a nunnery half a year.

column2: And Sir Pelleas was a worshipful knight, and was one of the four that achieved the Sangreal, and the Damosel of the Lake made by her means that never he had ado with Sir Launcelot de Lake, for where Sir Launcelot was at any jousts or any tournament, she would not suffer him be there that day, but if it were on the side of Sir Launcelot.
column3: And Sir Pelleas was a worshipful knight, and was one of the four that achieved the Sangreal, and the Damosel of the Lake made by her means that never he had ado with Sir Launcelot de Lake, for where Sir Launcelot was at any jousts or any tournament, she would not suffer him be there that day, but if it were on the side of Sir Launcelot.
